0.text:
Translator: Fran Ontanaya
Reviewer: Capa Girl

10.text: I want to talk to you about two

12.text: of the most exciting possible things.

16.text:
You probably guess what they are
-- data and history.

22.text: Right? So, I'm not a historian.

27.text:
I'm not going to give you
a definition of history,

29.text:
but let's think instead
of history within a framework.

32.text: So when we are making history

34.text:
or when we are creating
historical documents

37.text:
we are taking things that have
happened in the past

39.text:
and we are stitching them
together into a story.

42.text:
So let me start with a little bit
of my own story.

44.text:
Like anybody my age who
works creatively with computers

48.text:
I was a popular socially
well-adjusted young man --

59.text: And like a lot of people my age

62.text: in the kind of business that I'm in

64.text: I was influenced tremendously by Apple.

67.text: But notice my choice of logo here, right?

71.text:
The Apple on the left, not
the Apple on the right.

75.text:
I am influenced as much
by the Apple on the right

78.text:
as the next person. But
the apple on the left

81.text:
I mean look at that logo,
it's a rainbow --

83.text: It's not even in the right order!

89.text:
But I don't want to talk too
much about the company.

92.text: I'll start talking about a machine though.

94.text: How amazing it is to think about this,

97.text: and I go back and I think about this --

98.text: Wednesday, one Wednesday when I was

100.text:
about 12 years old,
I didn't have a computer.

104.text: On Thursday, I had a computer.

111.text:
It's so drastic, I can't
even think about anything

114.text: that could change our lives that way.

116.text:
But I'm actually not even going
to talk about the computer.

118.text: I'm going to talk about a program

120.text: that came loaded on that computer.

122.text:
And it was build by, not
the guy on the left,

124.text: but the guy on the right.

126.text:
Does anybody know who the guy
on the right is?

130.text:
Nobody ever knows the answer
to this question!

134.text:
And Bill Atkinson was responsible
for tons of things

137.text: that you see on your computer everyday.

139.text: But I want to talk about one program

141.text: that Bill Atkinson wrote called Hypercard.

145.text: Yeah -- someone is cheering over there.

149.text:
So, Hypercard was a program
that shipped with the Mac

152.text:
and it was designed
for users of the computer

154.text: to make programs on their computers.

158.text:
Crazy idea today. And
these programs were not

161.text: the apps that we think about today

162.text:
with their large budgets
and their big distribution.

165.text:
These were small things.
People making applications

167.text:
to keep track of their local
basketball team scores

173.text: or to teach people about classical music

176.text: or to calculate weird astronomical dates.

180.text:
And then, of course, there
were some art projects.

182.text:
This is my favourite one,
it's called 'If monks had Macs'

186.text:
and it's a non-linear kind
of exploratory environment.

190.text:
I thank the stars for Hypercard
all of the time.

196.text:
And I thank the stars
for putting me in this era

199.text: where I got to use Hypercard.

201.text: Hypercard was the last program to ship

204.text: on a public computer, that was designed

207.text:
for the users of the computer
to make programs with it.

211.text:
If you talked to the people
who invented the computer

213.text: and you told them there would be a day,

215.text:
a magical day, when
everybody had a computer

218.text: but none of them knew how to program,

221.text: they would think you were crazy!

224.text: So let's get forward a few years.

226.text: I'm starting my career as an artist

228.text:
and I'm building things
with my computer --

233.text: like the growth systems of plants.

236.text:
Or, in this example, I'm
building a simulated economy

239.text:
in which pixels are trading
colour with one another.

243.text:
Trying to investigate how these
types of systems work

245.text: and just kind of having fun.

247.text:
And then this project led me
to start working with data.

249.text: So I'm building graphics like this,

255.text:
the frequency of usage
of the word "communism"

258.text:
in the New York Times
to "terrorism" at the top.

260.text: So you see "terrorism" kind of appears

265.text:
And with these graphics
I was really interested

267.text: in the aesthetic of the graphs.

268.text: So, this is Iran and Iraq, it reads

270.text:
like a clock, it's called
the "timepiece graph"

274.text: And this is another timepiece graph

276.text: overlaying despair, I think, over hope

280.text:
and there's only three times
-- that's it, crisis

282.text:
over hope --
There's only three times when crisis

285.text:
eclipses hope. We
are in the middle of one of them

287.text:
right now -- but don't
think about that too much.

292.text: And finally the culmination of this work

295.text:
with the New York Times'
data a few years ago

297.text:
was the attempt to combine
an entire year's

299.text: news cycle into a single graphic.

301.text:
So these graphics actually
show us a full year

304.text:
of news, all the people,
and how they are connected

306.text: into a single graphic. And, from there

309.text: I started to be interested again

311.text:
in more active systems.
So, here's a project

313.text:
called "Just landed" where
I'm looking at people

316.text:
tweeting on Twitter "Hey!
I just landed in Hawaii!"

319.text:
You know how people just
casually try to sneak that

321.text:
into their twitter conversation.
"I'm not showing off!

324.text: Really! But I did just land in Hawaii."

326.text: And then I'm plotting those people's trips

329.text:
in the hopes that maybe
we can use social network

332.text: and the data that it leaves behind

334.text: to provide a model of how people move

336.text: which would be valuable to epidemiologists

339.text: among other people. And, more fun --

340.text:
this is a similar project
looking at people

344.text: all around the world. Which taught me

346.text: by the way, that it is true that people

348.text: in Vancouver on the West Coast wake up

351.text:
much later and say "good
morning" much later

353.text: than the people on the East Coast

357.text: Here's a more useful -- maybe -- project

359.text: where I took all the information

361.text: from the Kepler project and try to put it

363.text:
into some visual form
that made sense to me.

365.text:
And I should say
that everything I've shown you

367.text: up to now -- these are all things

369.text: that I just did for fun. It may seem weird

371.text: but this comes back from Hypercard.

375.text: I may share them with a few other people

377.text: but they are for fun, they are for me.

379.text: So all these tools I showed you

383.text: that kind of occupy this weird space --

386.text: somewhere between science, art and design

388.text: and that's where my practice lies.

390.text:
And still today
from my experience with Hypercard

393.text:
what I'm doing is I'm
building visual tools

398.text: So today I work at the New York Times --

401.text:
I'm the data artist
in residence at the NY Times --

403.text: and I've had the opportunity at the Times

405.text:
to work on a variety of really
interesting projects,

408.text:
two of which I'm going
to share with you today.

410.text:
The first one I've been working
on, in conjunction

412.text:
with Mark Hansen. Mark
Hansen is a professor

415.text:
of statistics at the UCLA.
He's also a media artist.

419.text:
And Mark came to the Times
with a very interesting question

422.text:
to what may seem
like an obvious problem --

424.text:
When people share content
on the Internet, how does

428.text:
that content get
from person A to person B?

432.text: Or, maybe person A to person B to person C

436.text:
to person D. We know
that people share content

438.text: in the Internet, but what we don't know

440.text: is what happens in that gap

441.text: between one person to the other.

443.text:
So we decided to build
the tool to explore that

448.text: So if we look at these systems that start

451.text: with one event that leads to other events.

457.text:
And these cascades
actually happen over time

460.text: so we can model these things over time.

462.text:
Now, the New York Times
has a lot of people

464.text: who share our contents, so the cascades

467.text:
do not look like that one,
they look more like this --

469.text: So here is the typical cascade.

471.text: At the bottom left, the very first event.

475.text: And then as people are sharing the content

477.text: from one person to another we go up

480.text: in the Y axis - degrees of separation -

483.text: and over on the X axis for time.

486.text:
So we are able to look
at that conversation

487.text: in a couple different views. This one

489.text:
which shows us the threads
of conversation.

492.text:
And this one which combines
that stacked view

495.text: with a view that lets us see the threads.

498.text:
Now the Times publishes
about seven thousand pieces

501.text:
of content every month. So
it was important for us,

504.text: when we were building this tool

505.text: to make it an exploratory one.

507.text:
So the people could dig
through this vast terrain

511.text: of data -- I think of it as a vehicle

513.text: that we are giving people to traverse

515.text: this really big terrain of data.

517.text: So here is what it really looks like

519.text:
and here is a cascade
playing in real time.

522.text:
I have to say, this
was a tremendous moment.

524.text:
We had been working
with canned data, fake data

528.text: for so long, that when we saw this

530.text:
for the first moment, it
was like an archaeologist

533.text:
who had just dusted
off these dinosaur bones.

538.text: and we were seeing it for the first time.

540.text:
These sharing structures
that underlie the Internet.

544.text:
And maybe the dinosaur
analogy is a good one

547.text:
because we are actually
making some probabilistic

550.text: guesses about how these things link.

551.text: So we are looking at some of these pieces

554.text:
and making some guesses
but we try to make sure

556.text:
that those are as statistically
rigorous as possible.

559.text: Now, tweets in this case, they become

562.text:
parts of stories, they become
parts of narratives.

566.text:
So we are building histories
here, but they are

568.text: very short term histories. And sometimes

571.text: these very large cascades are the most

573.text:
interesting ones,
but sometimes the small ones

576.text:
are also interesting. This
is one of my favourites

581.text:
It's a conversation
amongst rabbis about this article

585.text:
in the New York Times
about the fact that religious

588.text: workers don't get a lot of time off.

590.text: I guess Saturdays and Sundays are bad days

594.text:
So in this cascade there
is a group of rabbis

597.text:
having a conversation
about a New York Times' story.

599.text:
One of them has the best
Twitter name ever --

605.text:
But we wouldn't ever
found this if it weren't

610.text: This would just be sitting somewhere

612.text:
and we would have never
been able to see that.

614.text: But this exercise of taking single pieces

617.text:
of information and building
narrative structures,

625.text:
Now, I moved to New York
about two years ago.

627.text: And in New York everybody has a story

630.text:
that surrounds this
tremendously impactful event

636.text: And my own story with September 11th

638.text: has really become a more intricate one

642.text:
because I spent a great
deal of time working

645.text:
on a piece of the 9/11
memorial in Manhattan.

649.text:
So the central idea
about the 9/11 memorial

652.text:
is that the names in the memorial
are not laid out

655.text:
in alphabetical order,
or chronological order,

657.text: but instead they are laid out in a way

660.text:
in which the relationships
between the people

662.text:
who were killed are embodied
in the memorial.

666.text: Brothers are placed next to brothers,

668.text:
coworkers are placed together.
So, this memorial

672.text:
actually considers all of these
myriad connections

675.text: that were part of these people's lives.

678.text:
So I work with a company
called Local Projects

682.text:
to work on an algorithm
and a software tool

685.text:
to help the architects build
the layout for the memorial.

691.text:
and almost fifteen hundred of these
adjacency requests,

694.text:
these requests for connections.
So a very dense story,

698.text: a very dense narrative that becomes

700.text: an embodied part of this memorial.

703.text:
So I'm working with Jake
Barton, we produce

705.text:
the software tool,
which allows the architects

707.text:
to, first of all, generate
the layout that satisfied

711.text:
all of those adjacency
requests, but then second

714.text:
make little adjustments
where they needed to

716.text:
to tell the stories
that they wanted to tell.

722.text:
has an incredibly timely
concept in our era

725.text:
of social networks,
because these networks --

728.text:
these real-life networks
that make people's lives

731.text:
are actually embodied
inside of the memorial.

734.text:
And one of the most tremendously
moving experiences

737.text:
it's to go to the memorial
and see how these people

741.text: are placed next to each other,

743.text:
so that this memorial
is representing their own lives.

747.text: How does this effect our lives?

750.text: Well, I don't know if you remember, but,

752.text: in the spring, there was a controversy,

754.text:
because it was discovered
that, on the iPhone,

758.text: you were storing a tremendous amount

760.text:
of location data. So,
Apple responded saying,

764.text: this was not location data about you,

766.text:
it was location data
about wireless networks

768.text: that were in the area where you are.

770.text:
So it's not about you,
it's about where you are.

778.text:
It's like gold to researchers!
This mobility data --

781.text: human mobility data. So what we thought --

784.text:
we thought, "Man! How
many people have iPhones?"

787.text: How many of you have iPhones?

789.text:
So in this room we have
this tremendous database

793.text:
of location data that researchers
would really really like.

798.text: So we built this system called Open Paths,

801.text: which lets people upload their iPhone data

806.text: to share that data, to donate that data

808.text: to people that can actually put it to use.

811.text:
So Open Paths was a great
success as a prototype.

813.text:
We received thousands
of datasets, and we built

817.text:
this interface which allows
people to actually

819.text: see their lives unfolding from this traces

822.text: that are left behind on your devices.

825.text: Now, what we didn't expect was how moving

828.text:
this experience would be.
When I uploaded my data

831.text: I thought, "Big deal. I know where I live.

833.text:
I know where I work. What
am I going to see here?"

836.text: Well it turns out what I saw was

838.text: that moment I got off the plane

840.text: to start my new life in New York.

842.text: The restaurant where I had Thai food

845.text: this new experience of being in New York.

848.text: The day that I met my girlfriend.

855.text:
This is this Thai restaurant
on Amsterdam Avenue.

859.text: This is the moment I met my girlfriend.

863.text: See how that changes the first time

864.text: I told you about those stories,

866.text:
and the second time I told
you about those stories.

869.text:
Because what we do in the tool
inadvertently is --

872.text:
we put these pieces of data
into a human context.

875.text: And by placing data into a human context

878.text:
it gains meaning. And I think
this is tremendously

884.text:
our histories that are being
stored on these devices.

889.text: And by thinking about them that way,

892.text: putting them in a human context --

894.text: first of all what we do with our own data

896.text: is get a better understanding of the type

898.text: of information that we are sharing.

900.text:
But if we can do this
with other data, we can put

902.text:
data into a human context,
I think we can change

905.text:
a lot of things. Because,
it builds automatically

910.text:
empathy for the people
involved in these systems.

914.text:
And that in turn results
in a fundamental respect which

917.text:
I believe is missing
in a large part of technology.

921.text:
And we start to deal
with issues like privacy.

927.text:
are not just numbers,
but instead they are attached

929.text:
- they are tethered to pieces
of the real world.

932.text: They carry weight. By understanding that

934.text: the dialog becomes a lot different.

938.text: How many of you have ever clicked a button

940.text: that enables a third party to access

943.text: your location data on your phone?

948.text: So the third party is the developer,

953.text: the only party that never gets access

954.text: to this information is the first party!

958.text:
And I think that's because we think
about these pieces

961.text: of data in a strandred abstract way.

964.text:
We don't put them
into a context which I think

966.text: makes them a lot more important.

968.text:
So what I'm asking you
to do is really simple.

970.text:
Start to think about data
in a human context.

973.text:
Doesn't really take anything.
When you read

976.text:
stock prices, think about them
in a human context.

978.text: When you think about mortgage reports,

980.text: think about them in a human context.

982.text:
There's no doubt that big
data is big business.

986.text: There's an industry being developed here.

990.text: Think about how well we have done

992.text:
in previous industries
that we have developed

994.text:
involving resources --
not very well at all.

996.text:
And I think part of that problem
is that we have had

999.text: a lack of participation in these dialogues

1001.text: from multiple pieces of human society.

1005.text: So the other thing that I'm asking for

1008.text:
is an inclusion in this
dialogue from artists,

1011.text: from poets, from writers -- from people

1013.text:
who can bring a human element
into this discussion.

1017.text: Because I believe that this world of data

1020.text: is going to be transformative for us.

1023.text:
And unlike our attempts
with the resource industry

1026.text:
and our attempts
with the financial industry,

1029.text:
by bringing the human
element into this story

1031.text:
I think that we can take
it to tremendous places.
